How to Cite a Book in MLA 9 Format

Complete guide to citing books in MLA 9 including single and multiple authors, editions, and publishers

What an MLA 9 book citation is for

In MLA 9th edition, a book citation in your Works Cited list tells readers exactly which book you used and how to find it. A strong citation does two things at once. It gives credit to the author, and it provides a clear path for someone else to locate the same source. MLA‚Äôs format is designed to be consistent, readable, and easy to scan in an alphabetical list.

Your rules about author names matter because names are the first sorting tool in a Works Cited list. Using full first names improves clarity and avoids confusion between authors with similar initials. Inverting the first author‚Äôs name supports alphabetical ordering.

Core format for a book in MLA 9

Basic template

Author Last Name, First Middle. Title of Book. Publisher, Year.

That is the most common form for a print book. Each part has a purpose.

  • Author identifies who created the work.
  • Title of Book is italicized because a book is a complete, stand alone work.
  • Publisher indicates who issued the book.
  • Year helps readers distinguish editions and locate the correct version.

Punctuation and formatting rules to follow

  • Put a period after the author name.
  • Italicize the book title, then add a period.
  • After the publisher, use a comma, then the year, then a period.
  • Use full first names, not initials, in the author element, according to your assignment rules.
  • Invert only the first author in multi author citations.

Author rules (and why they matter)

One author

Format
- Last, First Middle.

Why it matters
- Inversion makes alphabetical sorting consistent.
- Full first names reduce ambiguity. For example, ‚ÄúJ. Smith‚Äù could refer to multiple writers, but ‚ÄúJordan Smith‚Äù is clearer.

Two authors

Format
- First author inverted, second author in normal order, joined by and.

Template
- Last, First Middle, and First Last. Title. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters
- MLA uses ‚Äúand‚Äù because it reads naturally and clearly signals a two author collaboration.
- Only the first author is inverted, which keeps the Works Cited alphabetized by the first author‚Äôs last name while keeping the second author‚Äôs name readable.

Three or more authors

Format
- List only the first author (inverted), then add et al.

Template
- Last, First Middle, et al. Title. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters
- It keeps the citation from becoming too long to scan easily.
- It still credits the lead author and signals there are additional contributors.

No author

Format
- Start with the title.

Template
- Title of Book. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters
- MLA avoids labels like ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù in this situation because they can be inaccurate.
- Using the title first keeps the Works Cited list consistent and searchable.

Practical note about alphabetizing: when you alphabetize by title, ignore leading articles like A, An, and The. You still write the title normally in the citation, you just do not use the article for alphabetizing.

2 to 3 complete examples with explanations

Example 1, one author book

Works Cited entry

Morrison, Toni. Beloved. Alfred A. Knopf, 1987.

What is happening here
- Morrison, Toni. The author is listed last name first, and the first name is written in full.
- Beloved. The title is italicized because it is a complete book.
- Alfred A. Knopf, 1987. Publisher comes first, then year. The comma between them is standard MLA punctuation.

Tip
- Keep the publisher name as it appears on the title page, but do not add business words like ‚ÄúInc.‚Äù or ‚ÄúLtd.‚Äù unless your instructor specifically asks.

Example 2, two authors book

Works Cited entry

Grazer, Brian, and Charles Fishman. A Curious Mind: The Secret to a Bigger Life. Simon and Schuster, 2015.

What is happening here
- Grazer, Brian, first author is inverted.
- and Charles Fishman. second author is not inverted, and ‚Äúand‚Äù is used between names.
- The title and subtitle are separated by a colon, and the full title is italicized.
- Publisher and year follow the title.

Common pitfall
- Do not invert the second author. Writing ‚ÄúFishman, Charles‚Äù would be incorrect under your rules for two authors and would also make the author element harder to read.

Example 3, three or more authors book

Works Cited entry

Gladwell, Malcolm, et al. Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know about the People We Don‚Äôt Know. Little, Brown and Company, 2019.

What is happening here
- Gladwell, Malcolm, et al. Only the first author is listed in full and inverted, then ‚Äúet al.‚Äù indicates additional authors.
- The book title is italicized, and the subtitle follows after a colon.
- Publisher and year complete the entry.

Common pitfall
- Do not list the second and third authors and then add ‚Äúet al.‚Äù Under your rules, ‚Äúet al.‚Äù comes right after the first author only.

Practical tips for getting book citations right

Use the title page, not the cover

Covers sometimes shorten titles or omit subtitles. MLA citations should reflect the title page information whenever possible.

Keep capitalization consistent

MLA uses title case for English titles. Capitalize the first word, the last word, and major words in between. Do not capitalize short prepositions or articles unless they start the title or subtitle.

Do not mix up publisher and printer

In most student citations, you want the publisher, not the printing company. The publisher is usually listed prominently on the title page or copyright page.

Pay attention to edition statements when relevant

If a book is not the first edition and that matters to your research, include the edition after the title and before the publisher, for example, ‚Äú2nd ed.‚Äù This helps readers locate the exact version you used.

Double check spacing and italics

  • Italicize the book title.
  • Do not put the book title in quotation marks.
  • Use one space after periods in your Works Cited entry.

Why these rules matter in academic writing

MLA formatting is not just about following a template. It is about making your research traceable and your writing credible. When citations are consistent, readers can quickly scan your Works Cited list, find the author or title, and locate the source. Using full first names, inverting the first author, and applying the correct multi author rules all support that goal. They reduce confusion, prevent misattribution, and make your academic work easier to verify.

Common Errors for Book Citation Mla Citations

Validation Checklist

Before submitting your Book Citation Mla citation, verify:

  • Author names MUST use full first names, not initials. In MLA 9, the emphasis is on full names to provide clarity and respect for the author's identity. The first author's name is inverted (Last, First Middle), while subsequent authors in two-author works use normal order (First Last).
  • First author name MUST be inverted (Last, First Middle). This applies to all source types and is the standard opening format for MLA citations. The inversion facilitates alphabetical ordering in the Works Cited list.
  • For TWO authors: use 'and' between names (second name NOT inverted). The word 'and' is preferred in MLA for its formality and readability.
  • For THREE OR MORE authors: use 'et al.' after first author only. Do not list additional authors before 'et al.' This simplifies lengthy author lists while maintaining proper attribution. The first author must still use full first name, not initials.
  • NO AUTHOR: Start with title (ignore 'A', 'An', 'The' for alphabetization). Do not use 'n.d.' or 'Anonymous'. The title becomes the first element and should maintain proper formatting (quotes for short works, italics for complete works).
  • ALL titles MUST use Title Case (capitalize all major words). This includes articles, books, websites, and all other sources. Title Case means capitalizing the first and last words, and all principal words (nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs). Articles (a, an, the), coordinating conjunctions, and prepositions are lowercase unless first or last word.
  • Shorter works use QUOTATION MARKS: Article titles, chapter titles, web page titles, poems, short stories, episodes. These are works that are part of a larger container. Quotation marks indicate the work is not standalone.
  • Complete works use ITALICS: Book titles, journal names, website names, films, TV series. These are standalone, self-contained works that serve as containers for shorter works. Italics indicate independence and completeness.
  • Do NOT use both italics AND quotation marks on same title. This is redundant and incorrect. Choose one based on whether the work is shorter (quotes) or complete (italics).
  • Date placement: AFTER publisher, BEFORE page numbers/URL. The date follows the publisher in the publication sequence.

Special Cases

Special cases and edge cases for MLA 9 book citations

MLA 9 book citations look simple at first, but books often come with extra contributors, multiple versions, unusual publishers, or missing information. These special cases matter because MLA citations are designed to help readers find the exact source you used. Small differences, like the edition or the translator, can point to a completely different text.

Your author name rules also matter for clarity and consistency. Using full first names supports accurate identification, and inverting the first author helps your Works Cited stay correctly alphabetized.

Below are common edge cases, what to do, and why it matters.

Core MLA 9 book template (baseline)

Use this as your starting point, then add special elements only when they apply.

Author. Title of Book. Publisher, Year.

Key reminders based on your rules:
- First author is inverted and uses full first name: Last, First Middle.
- Two authors: first author inverted, second author normal order, use and.
- Three or more authors: first author inverted, then et al.
- No author: start with the title.

Multiple authors and unusual author situations

Two authors (exact formatting)

If a book has two authors, list both. Only the first is inverted.

Format
- Last, First Middle, and First Last. Title. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: Readers can quickly scan for the lead author in alphabetical order, while still seeing the coauthor clearly.

Common pitfall: Inverting the second author too. MLA does not do that for two authors.

Three or more authors (use et al.)

If a book has three or more authors, list only the first author, then add et al.

Format
- Last, First Middle, et al. Title. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: It keeps citations readable and consistent, especially in Works Cited lists with many long entries.

Common pitfall: Listing the first two or three authors and then et al. Your rule says do not list additional authors before et al.

No author listed

If no author is credited, start with the title. Do not use ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù

Format
- Title of Book. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: MLA wants the citation to match what a reader sees on the title page. Using ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù can mislead readers, and ‚Äún.d.‚Äù is not MLA style for missing dates.

Practical tip: Use the title page, not the cover. The cover often omits editors, subtitles, or the real publisher.

Editors, translators, and other contributors

Books are often identified by people other than the main author, especially classics, anthologies, and translated works.

A book with an editor instead of an author

If the book is primarily credited to an editor, put the editor in the author position and add ‚Äúeditor‚Äù after the name.

Format
- Last, First Middle, editor. Title. Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: The editor is the main responsible contributor for that edition‚Äôs content and organization.

Common pitfall: Putting the editor after the title when there is no author. In MLA, the main credited person goes first.

A translated book

If your version is a translation, include the translator after the title.

Format
- Last, First Middle. Title. Translated by First Last, Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: Translations vary widely. The translator can affect wording, tone, and even interpretation. Naming the translator helps readers locate the same text.

An edited and translated book

Sometimes you have both. Include both roles after the title.

Format
- Last, First Middle. Title. Edited by First Last, translated by First Last, Publisher, Year.

Practical tip: Keep the roles in the order that best matches the title page credits. MLA is flexible, but consistency is important.

Editions, versions, and reprints

Later editions (2nd, 3rd, revised)

If the book is not the first edition, include the edition after the title.

Format
- Last, First Middle. Title. 2nd ed., Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: Page numbers, chapters, and even arguments can change across editions. Listing the edition helps readers verify quotations and track the correct version.

Common pitfall: Confusing a ‚Äúprinting‚Äù number with an edition. ‚ÄúSecond printing‚Äù is usually not the same as ‚Äú2nd edition.‚Äù If it only says ‚Äúprinting,‚Äù MLA usually does not require it unless it matters for your use.

Republished classics or modern reprints

If a book was originally published long ago but you used a modern reprint, cite the version you actually used. You can optionally add the original year if it is important to your discussion, but MLA‚Äôs main date is the one tied to your edition.

Practical tip: If your book shows multiple dates, choose the date that matches the publisher and edition you are holding, usually on the title page or copyright page.

Volumes, multivolume sets, and series

A single volume from a multivolume set

If you used one volume from a set, include the volume number after the title.

Format
- Last, First Middle. Title of Set. Vol. 2, Publisher, Year.

Why it matters: Without the volume, a reader may not know where to find the material.

A book in a named series

Series names are optional in MLA. Include them only if they help identify the book, for example, when many books share similar titles or when the series is central to your topic.

Common pitfall: Treating the series as the publisher. The publisher is the company that produced the book.

Publishers, places, and unusual publication info

Multiple publishers listed

MLA 9 generally uses one publisher, usually the one most responsible for the edition. If the title page lists multiple publishers, choose the one most relevant to your copy, often the first listed or the one tied to your country‚Äôs edition.

Practical tip: If the book clearly presents a co-publication that matters for identification, you can include both publishers, separated by a slash.

Missing publisher or date

Sometimes older or informal books omit standard details. MLA prefers you to cite what you can find, and omit what you cannot verify. Avoid guessing.

Common pitfall: Inserting ‚Äún.d.‚Äù for no date. MLA does not recommend that in Works Cited entries for books.

Examples (with explanations)

Example 1, two authors with full first names (correct name order)

Works Cited entry
- Gladwell, Malcolm, and Steven Levitt. Thinking About Evidence. Riverstone Press, 2021.

Why this is correct
- The first author is inverted: Gladwell, Malcolm.
- The second author is in normal order: Steven Levitt.
- It uses and, not an ampersand.
- The title is italicized because it is a complete book.
- Publisher and year finish the entry.

Common pitfalls
- Writing ‚ÄúLevitt, Steven‚Äù as the second author.
- Using initials like ‚ÄúM. Gladwell.‚Äù

Example 2, three or more authors, edition, and translator

Works Cited entry
- Garc√≠a M√°rquez, Gabriel, et al. One Hundred Years of Solitude. 3rd ed., translated by Edith Grossman, Vintage, 2006.

Why this is correct
- Three or more authors means first author plus et al. only.
- The edition appears after the title: 3rd ed.
- The translator is included because it is a translated work.
- The publisher and year identify the specific version used.

Common pitfalls
- Listing multiple authors before et al.
- Leaving out the edition, which can change pagination and wording.

Example 3, no author, edited collection

Works Cited entry
- The Norton Anthology of World Literature. Edited by Martin Puchner, W. W. Norton, 2018.

Why this is correct
- No author means the entry starts with the title.
- The editor is still credited after the title because it helps identify the exact anthology.
- The publisher and year complete the entry.

Common pitfalls
- Starting with ‚ÄúAnonymous.‚Äù
- Using the cover title if it differs from the full title on the title page.

Practical tips and common pitfalls (quick checklist)

Tips

  • Use the title page and copyright page for accurate details.
  • Keep author names consistent and complete, use full first names as required.
  • Include an edition only when it is clearly stated.
  • Add translators and editors when they shape the version you used.

Pitfalls to avoid

  • Inverting the second author in two-author books.
  • Listing multiple authors and then et al. in three-plus author books.
  • Using ‚Äún.d.‚Äù or ‚ÄúAnonymous.‚Äù
  • Guessing missing information instead of omitting it.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I cite a book in MLA format for my Works Cited page?

In MLA 9, a basic book entry usually follows this pattern: Author Last Name, First Name. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. Example: Morrison, Toni. Beloved. Vintage, 2004. Italicize the book title, and use a period after the author and the title. Use the publisher name as it appears on the title page, but you can omit business words like ‚ÄúInc.‚Äù or ‚ÄúLtd.‚Äù If the book has a DOI or stable URL and you accessed it online, add it at the end. If you used a specific edition, include it after the title, for example, ‚Äú2nd ed.‚Äù For a quick official overview, see the MLA style center: https://style.mla.org/works-cited-a-quick-guide/

How do I cite a chapter or essay from an edited book in MLA?

When you cite a chapter from an edited collection, you cite the chapter author first, then the chapter title in quotation marks, then the book title in italics, followed by the editor and publication details. A common format is: Chapter Author Last Name, First Name. ‚ÄúChapter Title.‚Äù Title of Book, edited by Editor First Name Last Name, Publisher, Year, pp. page range. Practical scenario: You quote a chapter by bell hooks in a reader edited by someone else. Your in-text citation uses the chapter author and the page number, not the editor. In Works Cited, include the page range so readers can find the chapter quickly. MLA‚Äôs guide to citing a work in a collection is helpful here: https://style.mla.org/works-cited-a-quick-guide/

How do I cite a book with two authors or three or more authors in MLA?

For two authors, list them in the order shown on the title page. The first author is Last Name, First Name, and the second author is First Name Last Name. Example: Garcia, Maria, and James Liu. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. For three or more authors, list the first author followed by ‚Äúet al.‚Äù Example: Nguyen, Linh, et al. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. Practical scenario: If your textbook lists four authors, you do not need to include all four in the Works Cited entry. In the in-text citation, use the first author‚Äôs last name and the page number, for example, (Nguyen 57). For more guidance on author formatting, see: https://style.mla.org/formatting-papers/

How do I cite an ebook in MLA, like a Kindle book or a PDF I downloaded?

Cite an ebook like a book, then add details about the digital version. Start with Author. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. Then include the platform or file type if it helps readers locate it, such as Kindle ed., PDF file, or the name of a database. If you accessed it online, include a DOI or stable URL at the end. Practical scenario: If your Kindle book has location numbers instead of page numbers, MLA recommends using chapter numbers or other stable markers in your in-text citation, for example, (Smith ch. 3). If the PDF has page numbers, use them. A useful resource for online works and URLs is: https://style.mla.org/dois-and-urls/

What if the book has no author, or the author is an organization?

If no individual author is listed, begin the Works Cited entry with the title in italics. Example: Title of Book. Publisher, Year. Then your in-text citation uses a shortened version of the title and the page number, for example, (Title 42). If the author is an organization, list the organization as the author, then the title and publication details. Practical scenario: You cite a report-style book published by the World Health Organization. Your entry begins: World Health Organization. Title of Book. Publisher, Year. If the publisher is the same as the organization, MLA often allows omitting the publisher to avoid repetition. More help with corporate authors appears here: https://style.mla.org/citing-corporate-authors/

How do I write MLA in-text citations for a book, especially if I mention the author in the sentence?

MLA in-text citations for books usually include the author‚Äôs last name and the page number, with no comma: (Lee 128). If you mention the author in your sentence, include only the page number in parentheses: Lee argues that the narrator is unreliable (128). Practical scenario: If you cite two different books by the same author, add a shortened title to distinguish them: (Lee, Quiet Streets 128) and (Lee, River Light 54). If there are no page numbers, as with some ebooks, use chapter, section, or another stable locator, such as (Lee ch. 5). For more on in-text citations, see: https://style.mla.org/in-text-citations/
